snippet: TO THE HOME SECTION:   History gives one a context for reflecting on the past, examining the present and looking toward the future. Therefore it is no surprise that Susan Barron [Hers, July 4] , describes past holders of the Presidency - all male ...
lead_paragraph: TO THE HOME SECTION: History gives one a context for reflecting on the past, examining the present and looking toward the future. snippet: Marymount Manhattan College has selected Judson R. Shaver, the provost and academic vice president at Iona College in New Rochelle, N.Y., as its next president, the first  man to hold the post since the college was founded 66 years ago.     ''We f...
lead_paragraph: Marymount Manhattan College has selected Judson R. Shaver, the provost and academic vice president at Iona College in New Rochelle, N.Y., as its next president, the first man to hold the post since the college was founded 66 years ago. ''We felt from the beginning that this was someone who understood where we had been and had a vision about where we might go,'' Mary Anne Schwalbe, head of the college's search committee, said in a statement. She added, ''A leader but also a listener was what we found when we talked to people who had worked for and with him.''
abstract: Marymount Manhattan College selects Judson R Shaver, provost and academic vice president at Iona College, as its next president; he will become first man to hold post since college was founded 66 years ago (M)

headline.main: Marymount Manhattan College Selects Its First Male President

snippet: Gilbert Cant article on male prostate gland; describes it, discusses its function, causes and symptoms of its diseases and treatment; says prostate disorders are among commonest afflictions of the modern male: 60% of N Amer men over age 60 have so...
abstract: Gilbert Cant article on male prostate gland; describes it, discusses its function, causes and symptoms of its diseases and treatment; says prostate disorders are among commonest afflictions of the modern male: 60% of N Amer men over age 60 have some enlargement of the prostate, and proportion rises to about 95% by age 80; gland is subject to infectious and noninfectious prostatis, but most feared of prostatic diseases is cancer; cancer originating in this gland is 3d commonest malignancy among N Amer males, and 3d-ranking cause of cancer deaths among men; article calls last qr of 20th century 'age of prostatism' because as more men live into advanced decades prostate trouble develops and because prostate disorder is now freely talked about; notes that US Interior Sec Rogers C B Morton is, so far, the highest placed Amer public official who has allowed public notice of his prostate trouble, cancer; he has no evidence of further difficulty following radiation treatment; comment by several drs cited; role of several drs in understanding and treating disorders noted; importance of early diagnosis stressed; illus; diagram (L)

headline.main: MALE TROUBLE; It's probably only a matter of time before a President discusses prostate disorder as freely as a President's wife discusses mastectomy

snippet: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. On Nov. 6 of this past year, Matina Horner, a 33-year-old associate professor of psychology at Harvard University, became the sixth president of Radcliffe College, the famed school for women founded in 1879 across the Cambridge Co...
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. On Nov. 6 of this past year, Matina Horner, a 33-year-old associate professor of psychology at Harvard University, became the sixth president of Radcliffe College, the famed school for women founded in 1879 across the Cambridge Common from Harvard. For great numbers of people--both inside and outside of the academic world -- Matina Horner's inauguration was a moment of ritual rather than of ceremony,

snippet: President Donald Trump's pick to fill a Supreme Court vacancy has heard dozens of workers' rights cases on the U.S. 10th Circuit Court of Appeals. Many conservatives hail Neil Gorsuch for sticking to the letter of the law and not letting personal ...
lead_paragraph: President Donald Trump's pick to fill a Supreme Court vacancy has heard dozens of workers' rights cases on the U.S. 10th Circuit Court of Appeals. Many conservatives hail Neil Gorsuch for sticking to the letter of the law and not letting personal views influence his rulings. Detractors note that he has, more often than not, sided with employers.
